column1: I: So to clarify did you expect that the code you clicked-and-dragged over was updated with references?

And then I think that all these methods they follow the same pattern and I don't see any reason to have them as different methods. I would have something like test functions - or a for-loop and if any of them broke I would have a message saying which one broke.
It goes beyond refactoring because - or I don't know does it? It goes beyond refactoring because now I'm squishing a bunch of methods into a single one but the behavior would still be the same.
It would still be a refactoring. It would be improving code quality. [26:16]

Errors.

Created a new class - actually I copied a class deleted a bunch of methods and then moved methods from one class to a new one. Making sure that I delete them - either delete or move. Making sure that the old class didn't have any signatures pointing to these new methods.
I: How did you make sure of that?
In the two cases I deleted I was quite sure.

You get an output when you delete something like you see the code being deleted so you're sure it's not there any more. If I was to push this I would do a git diff and I would make sure that everything is deleted. Even thought I have the visual prompt of what's done before doing a committ I do a git diff and I see the minus in front of any method signature to ensure that it was deleted and the file here.

I think they are ok I hope so.

Mostly because this static was the strangest thing that I saw so it would be the last piece of code to touch. I would improve the code first then I would get back to this static and see what happened if I delete it. Then you asked me to stop.

Yes that would be my workflow. This looks weird so it would be the last piece of code for me to touch.

It's a syntax I haven't seen before. It is weird for me but be normal for others.

Both.

Remove method isAnyNotBlank.
So that's where I would probably use maven. So I would delete it and run mvn build and see all the places that were not compiling.

I would go there and check. Something similar to this find usages. I would see these places and make sure that I delete them. So kind of like what I'm doing here. I don't like find usages so much because sometimes it keeps moving around in the window but in the terminal I can easily switch between the window and IDE and I have more space to look at the code.

I think so.

To solve the exercise. It is a compiled language so whatever I use to build will show me errors and then I will use these errors as guidelines. I don't know like .. it's probably something I don't use that often but I prefer to see these things happening step by step because I know what's there, I can double-check any of the files that are to be changed and see if there are any other changes that need to be done in them.

it casts this target object to the field class and then it calls the other one. I wondered how it wasn't getting a stackoverflow but now I realise that it is passing it on to someone else. I would not have noticed that if I was relying on automatic refactoring tools.
On one hand it may take longer for me to do the task but on the other I am getting more familiar with the code.

Righ now I have one compile error. And now I have compile errors in more than one location. Oh it's because of all the callees. So forceaccess an go. And then it should be gone. Ok. Run this guy again. I'll run the entire class. [1:34:55]

I: Can you elaborate?

When I was doing the changes at some point you asked me why I undid something I had done and I said it was because of too many errors. So I gave up on that and moved to another location and then I never had to touch any of the errors on the right hand side. So I think I did something different that resolved the errors or I deleted them I'm not quite certain. But I am sure that I didn't touch the test file as much as I was supposed to.
I: So you're telling me that you got some compile errors in the test file and they went away and you don't know why?
I don't. So that's... but I do know that I didn't do as many changes I was expecting to when I saw how many errors there were. I didn't do that many changes in the test file. [1:36:31]

I: What source code changes did you do in order to solve this task?
Moved blocks of code to methods that were being overriden and code deletion mostly. It's not that different from the previous task but there were more places to touch.
I: Can you explain in a bit more detail? [1:38:48]

There was a forceaccess method signature and all the other methods were calling that one with the parameter set to false. When I tried to delete this method I had to move the content from this method to the ones that was using it. That was for readField writeField declaredField .. I was moving all the content from these particular signatures to the ones that was calling it with the default parameter. When I had done that I could safely delete it.
I: And then you changed the tests as well?

Yes but for most of them it was code deletion because it didn't make sense to test something that was tested by another method. Again there were two signatures for each method and I made sure that there were still tests for one.
I: How did you organise your source code changes? You seemed to shift the organization while you worked.

That is a good question. A bit of trial and error. Trying to delete things and being guided by the compile errors. That is one of the benefits of a compiled language. You know where you are touching and some of the consequences. This one is fairly small. In a larger project as soon as I delete that i would see more things than the tests. Imagine that I delete X and there would be another 3-4 classes outside of the tests that uses X. Then I couldn't be guided with only visual cues for that, but for some scenarios there are maven so I could use the errors in maven. I am not used to building the project in the IDE.
I: Is that why you use mvn, to get it in a textual format?

Most Java projects are maven projects these days and whenever I have the option to work in the terminal,I prefer that. Even though the IDE is helpful it has a lot of indexing and things happening under the hoods, and that takes time and I prefer to write most comments in the terminal because it is faster. Then I can keep swapping between that. Getting back to the question, because this is an API and I am expecting my clients to use them, so the burden is on them. What I did was, I kept swapping between the files, and see how many errors I got and I tried to minimize the errors to know the places I had to work first and that seemed to work so i'm happy.
I: Would you have used the same apporach if you used maven to see how many errors you got and backtrack?
Yes same thing. Probably I would have two windows as well. [1:43:26]

I think the IDE is too bloated. Seeing all the errors in a small window like this one and trying to navigate it, clicking things, deleting things and trying to get back here it's quite hard. Whereas, in any terminal window it's static and I'm sure there's only going to change when I run a new command. 
 I don't know if you saw it, when I searched for something, I had a bunch of invalids in this window. That's annoying because when I go back there I can't see what I did any more. Whereas, if i had that information somewhere else it's easier to remember what I did, where I went to and backtrack.

I: How did you organize moving between changing the tests and the code inside the class itself. Sometimes you would go to the tests when there were errors and sometimes you would ignore those errors and keep working inside the class?

I started to realise some patterns. For example when I deleted some of the methods here with the illegal argument. In the beginning I went to the tests because I was not familiar with the class but as soon as I realised that there was another test testing the signature with a different parameter I knew I could delete the tests without being concerned with that. Throughout this task I started to realise these small patterns. In the beginning I was looking way more into the test cases but then I started ignoring it because I started seeing these things.
I: Do you know of any tools that ...
There may be a bunch of them I'm not sure. Not that I know of.
I: Would you consider using such a tool another time?
Perhaps? But again, it has to be very stepwise because I don't want to rely on a tool that will not help me become familiar with the source code. [1:46:37]

Not Satisfaction (“I don't want to rely on a tool that”)

column1: I'm quite certain that if I had to change this file again I would do it much faster because I started to see these dependencies. For example that thing casting a generic object to a field object, and if a tool does not give me that level of detail, when I try to use it to change the code it is not reliable. [1:47:08]

It pays off in time in the beginning but in the end when I have to do a really big feature change I will still be unfamiliar with the code. That's what I'm trying to avoid. I'd rather lose more time now in small changes rather than later on.
I: Is that true even if you're switching projects? You might not be working on this code for a long time in some imaginary scenario.

In such a scenario I would probably update a wiki or something for the next person to know that. The knowledge is not necessarily for only myself. I assume there should be some documentation or something there such that the next person will have less work than me.
I: what kinds of things would it say?
…no that's not a good example. [1:48:36]
For example this guy readfile with object and this other one reads the exessible and there is no class. [1:49:07]
The minimum example would be updating this documentation with this method uses the target class for reflecting on what field is being accessed and it caused that overload.
I: Do you think that should be part of the documentation or a wiki?

It doesn't matter. It is verbose and all of these things are the same. And there is actually a notation at see. I don't expect this to be a copy-paste of this but rather to explain the difference. It is done but in a very bad way I'd say. It's not distinct enough. You have to be aware that this target here is quite different from this field and you don't know that because there is still a target here.
I: It seems when you are working on this task and in particular the first one you wanted to make small readbility changes while you were working?
Of course.
I: If you were using an automated tool would that detract from your ability to do so?
Not necessarily. That depends on what the tool is doing. I think that .. you are asking if the tools would be able to do the small changes?

I: No. Say if the tool solved your problem say through a refactoring menu but it would take you through the code in the same way. Would you go and read the code in addition in order to be able to do all the readability?

I would do all the readability changes regardless. I would expect the tool to guide me through the code so I can double check the code and see how I can improve it. [1:51:52] If the tool is able to pinpoint me to all the location it is touching so I can backtrack to these places later that's fine. I don't want a button that just says it's done and then I don't know where unless I do a git diff or something like that.
column2:
Reflection
Not Predictable (“I don't want a button that just says it's done and then I don't know where”)

column1: I: You said that you wanted the tool to be very stepwise what did you mean with that?

When I'm doing a refactoring or let's pick the least complex example and expand from there. Say extract constant I use that refactoring because if I say replace all I see all occurrences and I see all of them flagged in that file. And that is stepwise for me because I see all the places the tool is touching and I can jump there later. But if a tool is like move to caller I want to see what kind of block is going to be moved and who else calls this function or at least see all the places of usages so I can touch these places later. Because otherwise how can I delete this and know where else needs to be checked. All these examples required deleting tests but none required flipping behavior. If a tool do not point me to a place where the flipping needs to happen then I would have the problem of doing a refactoring and not knowing if the behavior of the test should be the same or the behavior of the code.
column2:
Reflection
Predictable (“I see all of them”)

column1: I: What do you mean with flipping behavior?

Say you have return true and you have a bunch of tests with expect x to be true and because of some feature it should be false. When I run this code all of these tests will be broken. Some of the refactoring tools move the code and when I run the tests later I get an error and I don't know if I have to update the tests or. Ideally I would want to see all the places before doing anything. That's one of the reason I was flipping between. I wanted to only delete the tests when I was sure they were disposable. This should not be deleted this should be expect x to be false. [1:55:23] Right.

So ideally I would first update these guys before doing anything here so when I run them after the refactoring I would still get a green bar. And I expect tools to help me with that. When I say I'm moving these somewhere else I would expect the tool to say these are being used by x y z do you want to take a look at this? Or leave it there and let me navigate through the code. And once I understand that code I realise that what I want to do is fine I can say move forward. That's what I mean by stepwise.
I: In this case it sounded like when you were talking about it with refactoring you referred to the code and you talked about changing the tests almost like a separate thing. Did I get that right?

Yes because. I don't want a refactoring to touch the test cases. The tests exercises the code and if the refactoring touch the tests as well then I get back to the problem of did I change the behavior of the code or did I change the tests of my code and now I don't know which is the correct one. Imagine if you had these as services this guy would live in a different project.
I: The tests would live in a different project.
Yes. It's just a way to say it.
I: Do you usually use any refactoring tools?
Yes. Extract method extract constant. None of the big ones.
I: What would be a big one?

Moving functionality from a child class to a parent. I wouldn't rely on a refactoring tool for that because of my workflow. I wouldn't know who is using that thing and I want to know because I want to improve my understanding of the code for the future.
column2:
Reflection
Not Predictable ("I wouldn’t know who is using that ..”)

column1: I: If you use refactoring tools how do you make sure that they are correct?

Tests. I remember once that I had to do this thing of changing some database layer in one system and there were almost no tests there so before doing any refactoring I wrote a bunch of them. In the beginning I regretted it but then I found a bug. I was kind of like 20 different query parameters you coudl have and in one of them something was wrong. I only caught that because I had tests.
I: Did that become wrong because of the refactoring?
No it was the functionality that was wrong. But if I had done the refactoring before and I wrote the test later I would not have known if it was because of the refactoring or it was a bug there.
I: Can you summarize why you would usually use or not use a refactoring tool in this kind of task?

I use a refactoring when the changes are small enough that I am fully aware of where the code is going to change. Otherwise I prefer to do things manually. I konw it's more labor intensive but that helps me to get more familiar with the code and learn how I can improve the readability of the code. I'm picky with readability.

 Not Efficient (“I know it’s more labor intensive”)
